summary: A character reference letter written by Emily Waitt to Judge Alison J. Nathan on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell, requesting bail. The letter describes Maxwell's positive personal qualities and the writer's childhood memories of her, without addressing the criminal charges.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the character reference letter. The writer describes her as a strong, caring woman from her childhood perspective and advocates for her release on bail.

persons.name: Emily Waitt
persons.context: Author of the letter. She states she knew Maxwell from ages 10-17 while Maxwell was dating and living with her father, and she maintains contact with Maxwell.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The recipient of the letter, presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: Emily Waitt knew Maxwell as a child and young adult while Maxwell was in a relationship with her father. She describes Maxwell as a positive, caring figure in her life.

events.title: Character Reference Letter Submission
events.description: Emily Waitt submits a letter to Judge Alison J. Nathan advocating for Ghislaine Maxwell's release on bail.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Emily Waitt wrote a character reference letter for Ghislaine Maxwell to Judge Alison J. Nathan.
Waitt knew Maxwell from ages 10-17 while Maxwell was dating and living with her father.
The letter portrays Maxwell in a positive, caring light based on Waitt's childhood memories.
Waitt explicitly states she is not writing to discuss the charges or argue guilt/innocence, but to offer a personal perspective.
The letter's purpose is to support Maxwell's request for bail.
